items.name: Add event attachment
items.description: Adds an attachment to a specific Outlook calendar event. Use when you need to attach a file or nested item to an existing event.

input_parameters.description: Request parameters for adding an attachment to an Outlook calendar event.

contentBytes.description: Base64-encoded file contents; required when '@odata.type' is fileAttachment.
contentBytes.human_parameter_description: The file’s contents encoded in Base64 when attaching a file. Provide this only if you're adding a file attachment.
contentBytes.title: Content Bytes

event_id.description: The unique identifier of the calendar event to which the attachment will be added.
event_id.human_parameter_description: The unique ID of the event you want to attach the file or item to. You can get this from a previous event search or list.
event_id.title: Event Id

item.description: The nested item payload; required when '@odata.type' is itemAttachment.
item.human_parameter_description: The details of the Outlook item you want to attach (such as an email or another event). Provide this only for item attachments.
item.title: Item

name.description: The display name of the attachment.
name.human_parameter_description: The name that will appear for the attachment in the event (for example, 'agenda.pdf').
name.title: Name

odata_type.human_parameter_description: Choose whether you're attaching a file or an Outlook item. This determines which fields you need to fill in.
odata_type.title: Odata Type

user_id.description: The user's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address of the calendar owner whose event you want to attach to. Use 'me' to use your own account.
user_id.title: User Id

items.name: Add mail attachment
items.description: Tool to add an attachment to an email message. Use when you have a message ID and need to attach a small (<3 MB) file or reference.

input_parameters.description: Request model to add an attachment to a specific Outlook email message.

contentBytes.description: Base64-encoded content of the file attachment (max size 3 MB).
contentBytes.human_parameter_description: The file’s contents encoded as base64 text. Provide the data for the file you want to attach (up to 3 MB).
contentBytes.title: Content Bytes

contentId.description: Content ID for inline attachments, used in HTML body references.
contentId.human_parameter_description: If the attachment is inline, provide an ID you can reference from the email’s HTML (e.g., using cid:your-id).
contentId.title: Content Id

contentLocation.description: URL location or path for reference attachments.
contentLocation.human_parameter_description: A URL or path to where the content lives if you’re linking to it rather than embedding the file.
contentLocation.title: Content Location

contentType.description: MIME type of the attachment (e.g., 'application/pdf').
contentType.human_parameter_description: The file’s type (for example, 'application/pdf' or 'image/png') so email apps know how to open it.
contentType.title: Content Type

isInline.description: Set to true if the attachment should appear inline in the message body.
isInline.human_parameter_description: Choose whether the attachment should appear inside the email body instead of as a separate download.
isInline.title: Is Inline

item.description: Embedded item (e.g., message, event) for itemAttachment; must include its own '@odata.type'.
item.human_parameter_description: Use this only when attaching another item (like an email or calendar event). Include the item's details and its '@odata.type'.
item.title: Item

message_id.description: Unique identifier of the email message to attach to.
message_id.human_parameter_description: The unique identifier of the email message you want to attach the file to. You can get this from a previous message search or list operation.
message_id.title: Message Id

name.description: Display name of the attachment (e.g., file name).
name.human_parameter_description: The name you want shown for the attachment, like 'report.pdf' or 'image.png'. This is what recipients will see.
name.title: Name

odata_type.description: The OData type of the attachment. For file attachments, use '#microsoft.graph.fileAttachment'.
odata_type.human_parameter_description: Tells the system what kind of attachment you're adding. For a regular file, use '#microsoft.graph.fileAttachment'.
odata_type.title: Odata Type

user_id.description: The user's principal name or 'me' for the authenticated user.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or identifier of the user whose mailbox you want to access. Use 'me' to access your own mailbox.
user_id.title: User Id

items.name: Create Calendar Event
items.description: Creates a new Outlook calendar event, ensuring `start_datetime` is chronologically before `end_datetime`.

input_parameters.description: Defines the request schema for creating a new event in an Outlook calendar.

attendees_info.description: A list of attendees for the event. Can be simple email strings (e.g., ['user@example.com']) or attendee objects with 'email' (required), 'name' (optional), and 'type' (optional: 'required', 'optional', 'resource', defaults to 'required').
attendees_info.human_parameter_description: People you want to invite to the event. You can provide just email addresses as strings, or include additional details like names and whether they're required or optional attendees.
attendees_info.title: Attendees Info

body.description: The body of the event. This can be in plain text or HTML format, as specified by the 'is_html' field. Optional - events can be created without a body.
body.human_parameter_description: The details you want to share about the event—agenda, notes, links, or instructions for attendees.
body.title: Body

categories.description: A list of categories associated with the event. These categories must already exist in the user's mailbox.
categories.human_parameter_description: Optional labels to organize the event. Use categories that already exist in your mailbox.
categories.title: Categories

end_datetime.description: The end date and time of the event in ISO 8601 format. Time zone is specified in 'time_zone'.
end_datetime.human_parameter_description: When the event ends. Enter the date and time in the same time zone as Start.
end_datetime.title: End Datetime

is_html.description: Specifies whether the 'body' content is HTML. Set to true for HTML content; otherwise, it's treated as plain text.
is_html.human_parameter_description: Choose whether your event details are formatted as HTML (with styling and links) or plain text.
is_html.title: Is Html

is_online_meeting.description: Set to true to indicate that the event is an online meeting. This will automatically generate an online meeting link if 'online_meeting_provider' is set (e.g., a Microsoft Teams link).
is_online_meeting.human_parameter_description: Turn this on to add an online meeting link to the event.
is_online_meeting.title: Is Online Meeting

location.description: The physical location of the event.
location.human_parameter_description: Where the event will take place. Enter a room name, address, or leave blank for online-only meetings.
location.title: Location

online_meeting_provider.description: Specifies the online meeting provider. Currently, only 'teamsForBusiness' is supported. If 'is_online_meeting' is true and this is set, a meeting link for the provider will be created.
online_meeting_provider.human_parameter_description: Which service to use for the online meeting (for example, Microsoft Teams). Only set this if you’re creating an online meeting.
online_meeting_provider.title: Online Meeting Provider

show_as.description: The status to show on the calendar for the duration of the event. Valid values are: 'free', 'tentative', 'busy', 'oof' (out of office), 'workingElsewhere', 'unknown'.
show_as.human_parameter_description: How your availability appears on your calendar during the event (for example, Busy or Free).
show_as.title: Show As

start_datetime.description: The start date and time of the event in ISO 8601 format. Time zone is specified in 'time_zone'.
start_datetime.human_parameter_description: When the event starts. Enter the date and time; the Time Zone field decides how it’s interpreted.
start_datetime.title: Start Datetime

subject.description: The subject of the calendar event.
subject.human_parameter_description: A short title for the event so everyone knows what it’s about.
subject.title: Subject

time_zone.description: The time zone for the start and end times of the event. Uses Windows time zone names (e.g., 'Pacific Standard Time') or IANA time zone names (e.g., 'America/Los_Angeles'). UTC is also a valid input.
time_zone.human_parameter_description: The time zone to apply to the start and end times. Pick the zone that matches where the event is scheduled.
time_zone.title: Time Zone

user_id.description: The UPN (User Principal Name) or object ID of the user whose calendar the event will be created in. Use 'me' for the currently authenticated user.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or identifier of the user whose calendar you want to use. Use 'me' to create the event on your own calendar.
user_id.title: User Id

items.name: Create email draft
items.description: Creates a new Outlook email draft with subject, body, recipients, and an optional attachment. This action creates a standalone draft for new conversations. To create a draft reply to an existing conversation/message, use the OUTLOOK_CREATE_DRAFT_REPLY action instead.

mimetype.description: The MIME type of the file
mimetype.title: Mimetype

name.description: The filename that will be used when uploading the file to the destination service
name.title: Name

s3key.description: The S3 key of a publicly accessible file, typically returned from a previous download action that stored the file in S3. This key references an existing file that can be uploaded to another service.
s3key.title: S3Key

attachment.description: Optional file to attach. If provided, must include the file's content, name, and mimetype.
attachment.human_parameter_description: A file to include with your draft, like a document or image. Add it if you want recipients to download or view the file.
attachment.title: Attachment

bcc_recipients.description: Optional list of BCC (blind carbon copy) recipient email addresses. Must be provided as an array of strings, e.g., ["bcc@example.com"].
bcc_recipients.human_parameter_description: People who should receive a hidden copy. Other recipients won't see these addresses.
bcc_recipients.title: Bcc Recipients

body.description: Content of the email draft; use `is_html` to specify if HTML or plain text.
examples: Let's meet to discuss the project.
body.human_parameter_description: What you want to say in the email. Write your message here; turn on 'Is HTML' if you want to include formatting like bold text or links.
body.title: Body

cc_recipients.description: Optional list of CC (carbon copy) recipient email addresses. Must be provided as an array of strings, e.g., ["cc@example.com"].
cc_recipients.human_parameter_description: People you want to keep in the loop. They'll receive a copy of the email but aren't the primary recipients.
cc_recipients.title: Cc Recipients

is_html.description: Specifies if the `body` is HTML. If `False`, `body` is plain text.
is_html.human_parameter_description: Choose whether your message body uses rich formatting (HTML) or plain text. Turn this on if you want styles, links, or images to render.
is_html.title: Is Html

subject.description: Subject line for the email draft.
subject.human_parameter_description: The subject line you want people to see in their inbox. Keep it short and clear so recipients know what the email is about.
subject.title: Subject

to_recipients.description: Optional list of primary 'To' recipient email addresses. Must be provided as an array of strings, e.g., ["user@example.com"] for a single recipient or ["user1@example.com", "user2@example.com"] for multiple recipients. Do not pass as a JSON-encoded string. Can be omitted when creating a draft to be completed later.
to_recipients.human_parameter_description: The main people you're emailing. Enter one or more email addresses as an array. Leave empty if you'll add recipients later.
to_recipients.title: To Recipients

items.name: Create a draft reply
items.description: Creates a draft reply in the specified user's Outlook mailbox to an existing message (identified by a valid `message_id`), optionally including a `comment` and CC/BCC recipients.

examples: Thank you for your email. I'll review and respond shortly.

message_id.description: Required. Unique ID of the message to reply to. Obtain this from actions like 'List Messages', 'Get Message', or 'Search Messages'.

user_id.title: User Id

Useful for domain matching (e.g., '@openai.com') or pattern matching (e.g., 'noreply', 'no-reply', 'notifications'). More flexible than fromAddresses which requires exact matches.

sequence.description: Order in which the rule is executed (lower numbers execute first).

items.name: Create mail folder
items.description: Tool to create a new mail folder. Use when you need to organize email into a new folder.

input_parameters.description: Defines the request schema for creating a new mail folder in the user's mailbox.

displayName.description: The display name of the new mail folder.
displayName.human_parameter_description: The name you want to give the new mail folder. Pick a clear, descriptive title so you can easily find it later.
displayName.title: Display Name

isHidden.description: Indicates whether the new folder is hidden. Default is false. Once set, this property cannot be updated.
isHidden.human_parameter_description: Choose whether the new folder should be hidden from your usual folder list. Use this if you want the folder out of sight for a cleaner mailbox.
isHidden.title: Is Hidden

return_existing_if_exists.description: If true and a folder with the same name already exists, return the existing folder instead of raising an error. This makes the operation idempotent.
return_existing_if_exists.human_parameter_description: Enable this to make folder creation idempotent. If a folder with the same name already exists, the existing folder will be returned instead of an error.
return_existing_if_exists.title: Return Existing If Exists

user_id.description: Identifier for the user whose mailbox the folder will be created in. Use 'me' for the authenticated user or provide the user's principal name or ID.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or identifier of the user whose mailbox you want to create the folder in. Use 'me' to create it in your own mailbox.
user_id.title: User Id

input_parameters.title: CreateMailFolderRequest

childFolderCount.description: Number of immediate child mailFolders in the current mailFolder.
childFolderCount.title: Child Folder Count

composio_execution_message.description: Message explaining any modifications or special handling during execution.
composio_execution_message.title: Composio Execution Message

displayName.description: The mailFolder's display name.
displayName.title: Display Name

id.description: The mailFolder's unique identifier.
id.title: Id

isHidden.description: Indicates whether the mailFolder is hidden. This property can only be set on creation and cannot be modified afterwards.
isHidden.title: Is Hidden

parentFolderId.description: Unique identifier for the mailFolder's parent mailFolder.
parentFolderId.title: Parent Folder Id

totalItemCount.description: Total number of items in the mailFolder.
totalItemCount.title: Total Item Count

unreadItemCount.description: Number of items in the mailFolder marked as unread.
unreadItemCount.title: Unread Item Count

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: Create master category
items.description: Tool to create a new category in the user's master category list. Use after selecting a unique display name.

input_parameters.description: Request schema for creating a new Outlook master category in the user's mailbox.

color.description: A pre-set color constant for the category. Allowed values: preset0 through preset24.
color.human_parameter_description: Pick a color to help you visually spot this category. Leave it blank if you’re not sure—you can set or change it later.
color.title: Color

displayName.description: Unique name that identifies the category in the user's mailbox.
displayName.human_parameter_description: The name you want to give this category, like 'Project expenses' or 'Urgent'. Choose a unique, memorable name so you can easily find and apply it later.
displayName.title: Display Name

input_parameters.title: CreateMasterCategoryRequest

@odata.context.description: The OData context URI identifying the metadata endpoint for the response.
@odata.context.title: @Odata.Context

color.description: A pre-set color constant that characterizes the category, mapped to one of 25 predefined colors. Possible values include 'None', 'preset0' through 'preset24'. Each preset constant is mapped to a color that depends on the Outlook client displaying the categories.
color.title: Color

displayName.description: A unique name that identifies the category in the user's mailbox. After a category is created, the name cannot be changed. This value is read-only after creation.
displayName.title: Display Name

id.description: Unique identifier for the category. This is a read-only system-generated value that uniquely identifies the category in the user's mailbox.
id.title: Id

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: Decline calendar event
items.description: Tool to decline an invitation to a calendar event. Use when the user wants to decline a meeting or event invitation. The API returns 202 Accepted with no content on success.

input_parameters.description: Request model for declining a calendar event invitation.

comment.description: Optional text message to include in the response to the event organizer explaining the decline.
examples: I have a conflict at that time.
comment.title: Comment

event_id.description: The unique identifier of the calendar event to decline.

items.name: Get mail delta
items.description: Retrieve incremental changes (delta) of messages in a mailbox. FIRST RUN: Returns ALL messages in folder (use top=50 to limit). Response has @odata.deltaLink. SUBSEQUENT: Pass stored deltaLink to get only NEW/UPDATED/DELETED messages since last sync. Properties available: id, subject, from, receivedDateTime, isRead, etc. NOT available: internetMessageHeaders, full body, attachment content (response size limits).

input_parameters.description: Request schema for retrieving incremental changes (delta) of messages in a mailbox.

delta_token.description: Delta token from a previous call to get only changes since that state. If delta_token is not provided, the API returns all messages in the folder (initial sync). Use top parameter (e.g., top=50) on first run to limit results. Response includes @odata.deltaLink - extract and store this for next call to get only new changes. Subsequent calls with deltaLink return only: new messages, updated messages, deleted message IDs.
delta_token.human_parameter_description: Paste the delta token or deltaLink from your previous sync to fetch only changes since then. This makes follow-up syncs much faster.
delta_token.title: Delta Token

expand.description: List of related entities to expand (e.g. ['attachments']).
expand.human_parameter_description: Include related details with each message, such as attachments, when available.
expand.title: Expand

folder_id.description: Mail folder identifier to scope the delta query to that folder (e.g., 'Inbox' or folder ID GUID). Defaults to Inbox when omitted.
folder_id.human_parameter_description: The folder you want to track for message changes, like 'Inbox' or a specific folder ID. Leave blank to use Inbox by default.
folder_id.title: Folder Id

select.description: List of message properties to include (e.g. ['subject','receivedDateTime']). Delta sync has property limitations due to response size constraints. Not available in delta: internetMessageHeaders, body (full), attachments (full content). Available: id, subject, from, toRecipients, ccRecipients, bccRecipients, receivedDateTime, sentDateTime, isRead, isDraft, importance, hasAttachments, categories, conversationId, flag, webLink, bodyPreview (first 255 chars).
select.human_parameter_description: Choose the message fields you need (like subject or received time) to keep responses small and fast.
select.title: Select

skip_token.description: Skip token for paging through large result sets during initial sync. Automatically provided in response '@odata.nextLink' when there are more results. Extract from nextLink URL and pass here for next page. Keep paginating until you receive '@odata.deltaLink' instead of nextLink.
skip_token.human_parameter_description: If your initial sync has more pages, paste the next page token here to continue where you left off.
skip_token.title: Skip Token

top.description: Maximum number of items to return per page. For first run without delta_token, use top=50 or top=100 to limit results. First delta call without token returns all messages in folder. Paginate through results using @odata.nextLink, then store @odata.deltaLink for next sync.
top.human_parameter_description: How many messages to load per page. Use a modest number (e.g., 50–100) on the first run to keep results manageable.
top.title: Top

user_id.description: User identifier: 'me' for the signed-in user or the user's email/UPN.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or identifier of the mailbox you want to sync. Use 'me' to sync your own mailbox.
user_id.title: User Id

items.name: Get mail tips
items.description: Tool to retrieve mail tips such as automatic replies and mailbox full status. Use when you need to check recipient status before sending mail.

EmailAddresses.description: Collection of SMTP addresses of recipients to get MailTips for.

MailTipsOptions.description: List of mail tip types to retrieve for each recipient.

user_id.title: User Id

items.name: List events
items.description: Retrieves events from a user's Outlook calendar via Microsoft Graph API. Supports primary/secondary/shared calendars, pagination, filtering, property selection, sorting, and timezone specification. Use calendar_id to access non-primary calendars.

calendar_id.description: Optional ID of a specific calendar to retrieve events from.If not provided, uses the primary calendar. Get calendar IDs using LIST_CALENDARS action. Useful for accessing secondary calendars, shared calendars, or team calendars.
calendar_id.human_parameter_description: The specific calendar to pull events from. Leave blank for your primary calendar; use this if you want a secondary or shared calendar.
calendar_id.title: Calendar Id

expand_recurring_events.description: When true, automatically expands recurring events to show actual occurrences within the filtered date range instead of series masters. When false (default), returns series masters as before.
expand_recurring_events.human_parameter_description: Show each occurrence of recurring meetings within your date range instead of just the series. Turn this on if you need the individual instances.
expand_recurring_events.title: Expand Recurring Events

filter.description: OData query string to filter events. DateTime values MUST include: (1) Single quotes around the value, (2) Timezone offset suffix (Z for UTC or +/-HH:MM). Format: "start/dateTime ge 'YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ'". Example: "start/dateTime ge '2024-07-01T00:00:00Z' and start/dateTime le '2024-07-31T23:59:59Z'". Common operators: ge (>=), le (<=), eq (=), gt (>), lt (<). DateTime values without quotes or timezone suffix will be automatically normalized.
filter.human_parameter_description: A simple way to narrow the list, like limiting to a date range or matching a subject. Use it to only return events you care about.
filter.title: Filter

orderby.description: List of properties to sort results by. Each item is a string like 'start/dateTime desc' or 'subject asc'. MUST be provided as a list, even for single sort criteria. Use 'asc' (default) or 'desc' for order.
orderby.human_parameter_description: Choose how to sort the results (for example: by start time or subject). Add 'desc' to see the latest or highest first.
orderby.title: Orderby

select.description: List of specific event property names to return. Each item is a property name like 'subject' or 'start'. MUST be provided as a list. If omitted, a default set of properties is returned.
select.human_parameter_description: Pick which details to include for each event (for example: subject, start, end). This helps keep the response concise and focused.
select.title: Select

skip.description: Number of initial events to bypass, used for pagination.
skip.human_parameter_description: How many events to skip from the beginning of the list. Use this to jump ahead when paging through results.
skip.title: Skip

timezone.description: Preferred IANA or Windows timezone for event start/end times (e.g., 'America/New_York'); defaults to UTC if unspecified/invalid.
timezone.human_parameter_description: The time zone to display event start and end times in. Choose your local time zone for easier reading.
timezone.title: Timezone

top.description: Maximum number of events to retrieve per page for pagination.
top.human_parameter_description: How many events to return in this batch. Increase to see more results at once.
top.title: Top

user_id.description: Email address of the target user (or 'me' for authenticated user), identifying the calendar for event listing.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or user identifier of the calendar you want to read. Use 'me' to access your own calendar.
user_id.title: User Id

@odata.nextLink.description: URL for the next page of results when pagination is used.
@odata.nextLink.title: @Odata.Next Link

items.name: List mail folders
items.description: Tool to list a user's top-level mail folders. Use when you need folders like Inbox, Drafts, Sent Items; set include_hidden_folders=True to include hidden folders.

input_parameters.description: Request parameters for listing mail folders in a user's mailbox.

include_hidden_folders.description: Include hidden mail folders (isHidden=true) when set to true.
include_hidden_folders.human_parameter_description: Choose whether to include folders that are normally hidden. Turn this on if you want to see system or special folders that don't usually appear.
include_hidden_folders.title: Include Hidden Folders

user_id.description: User's id, userPrincipalName, or 'me' for the signed-in user.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or identifier of the user whose mailbox you want to access. Use 'me' to access your own mailbox.
user_id.title: User Id

input_parameters.title: ListMailFoldersRequest

items.name: List Messages
items.description: Retrieves a list of email messages from a specified mail folder in an Outlook mailbox, with options for filtering (including by conversationId to get all messages in a thread), pagination, and sorting; ensure 'user_id' and 'folder' are valid, and all date/time strings are in ISO 8601 format.

categories.description: Filter by categories (case-sensitive); matches if tagged with any specified category.
categories.human_parameter_description: Return emails tagged with any of these categories.
categories.title: Categories

conversationId.description: Filter messages by conversation ID to retrieve all messages in a specific email thread.
conversationId.human_parameter_description: Get all emails that belong to a specific conversation or thread by its ID.
conversationId.title: Conversation Id

folder.description: ID or well-known name of the mail folder. Well-known names (case-insensitive): archive, clutter, conflicts, conversationhistory, deleteditems, drafts, inbox, junkemail, localfailures, msgfolderroot, outbox, recoverableitemsdeletions, scheduled, searchfolders, sentitems, serverfailures, syncissues. Or use a valid folder ID (alphanumeric string like 'AAMkAGI0ZjExAAA='). Invalid or malformed folder identifiers will be rejected.
folder.human_parameter_description: The folder to list emails from, like 'inbox' or 'sentitems'. You can also paste a specific folder ID.
folder.title: Folder

from_address.description: Filter by the sender's exact email address. NOTE: This filter is applied client-side on the returned results, not server-side.
from_address.human_parameter_description: Only include emails sent from this exact email address.
from_address.title: From Address

has_attachments.description: Filter by attachment presence: 'true' for messages with attachments, 'false' for those without. NOTE: This filter is applied client-side on the returned results.
has_attachments.human_parameter_description: Choose whether to return only emails with attachments or only those without.
has_attachments.title: Has Attachments

importance.description: Filter by importance: 'low', 'normal', or 'high'.
importance.human_parameter_description: Limit results to emails marked low, normal, or high importance.
importance.title: Importance

is_read.description: Filter by read status: 'true' for read, 'false' for unread. Unspecified means no filter by read status.
is_read.human_parameter_description: Choose whether to show only read or only unread emails. Leave blank to include both.
is_read.title: Is Read

orderby.description: Properties to sort results by, with direction. Accepts a list of strings or a comma-separated string. Each item should be like 'receivedDateTime desc' or 'subject asc'. Default is 'receivedDateTime desc'. Cannot be used with sentDateTime filters in Sent folder.
orderby.human_parameter_description: Choose how to sort the results, such as newest first or by subject.
orderby.title: Orderby

received_date_time_ge.description: Filter messages received on or after this ISO 8601 timestamp.
received_date_time_ge.human_parameter_description: Include emails received on or after this date and time.
received_date_time_ge.title: Received Date Time Ge

received_date_time_gt.description: Filter messages received after this ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., '2023-01-01T00:00:00Z').
received_date_time_gt.human_parameter_description: Only include emails received after this date and time.
received_date_time_gt.title: Received Date Time Gt

received_date_time_le.description: Filter messages received on or before this ISO 8601 timestamp.
received_date_time_le.human_parameter_description: Include emails received on or before this date and time.
received_date_time_le.title: Received Date Time Le

received_date_time_lt.description: Filter messages received before this ISO 8601 timestamp.
received_date_time_lt.human_parameter_description: Include emails received before this date and time.
received_date_time_lt.title: Received Date Time Lt

select.description: Message properties to include. Accepts a list of strings or a comma-separated string (e.g., 'id,subject,from'). Valid properties: id, subject, from, toRecipients, ccRecipients, bccRecipients, receivedDateTime, sentDateTime, hasAttachments, importance, isRead, body, bodyPreview, categories, conversationId, conversationIndex, flag, internetMessageHeaders, parentFolderId, replyTo, sender, webLink, isDraft, isReadReceiptRequested, isDeliveryReceiptRequested, changeKey, createdDateTime, lastModifiedDateTime, inferenceClassification, size, internetMessageId. Note: attachments is not selectable.
select.human_parameter_description: Choose which fields to return for each email (for example, subject or from) to keep results concise.
select.title: Select

sent_date_time_gt.description: Filter messages sent after this ISO 8601 timestamp.
sent_date_time_gt.human_parameter_description: Only include emails sent after this date and time.
sent_date_time_gt.title: Sent Date Time Gt

sent_date_time_lt.description: Filter messages sent before this ISO 8601 timestamp.
sent_date_time_lt.human_parameter_description: Only include emails sent before this date and time.
sent_date_time_lt.title: Sent Date Time Lt

skip.description: Number of messages to skip from the beginning of the result set, for pagination.
skip.human_parameter_description: How many emails to skip from the start of the list, helpful when paging through results.
skip.title: Skip

subject.description: Filter by exact match of the subject line. Special characters like apostrophes, brackets will be automatically escaped. For complex subject searches, consider using 'Search Messages' instead.
subject.human_parameter_description: Only return emails whose subject matches this text exactly. For broader matches, try 'Subject Contains' or the search action.
subject.title: Subject

subject_contains.description: Filter messages where the subject contains the specified case-insensitive substring. NOTE: This filter is applied client-side on the returned results. For better performance, use 'Search Messages' instead.
subject_contains.human_parameter_description: Only include emails whose subject contains this text.
subject_contains.title: Subject Contains

subject_endswith.description: Filter messages where the subject ends with the specified case-insensitive string. NOTE: This filter is applied client-side on the returned results. For better performance, use 'Search Messages' instead.
subject_endswith.human_parameter_description: Only include emails whose subject ends with this text.
subject_endswith.title: Subject Endswith

subject_startswith.description: Filter messages where the subject starts with the specified case-insensitive string.
subject_startswith.human_parameter_description: Only include emails whose subject starts with this text.
subject_startswith.title: Subject Startswith

top.description: Maximum number of messages to return per request (1-1000). Always check response['@odata.nextLink'] for pagination. If present, make additional requests with that URL (includes $skiptoken). Repeat until '@odata.nextLink' is absent. For large mailboxes (1000+ messages), always paginate.
top.human_parameter_description: How many emails to return in this request (up to 1000). Use a larger number to see more at once.
top.title: Top

user_id.description: Target user's email or 'me' for authenticated user. For delegated access, use shared mailbox or delegated user's email.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address of the mailbox you want to access. Use 'me' to work with your own mailbox.
user_id.title: User Id

@odata.context.title: @Odata.Context

@odata.nextLink.description: URL for pagination to retrieve the next page of results. Apply the entire URL returned to the next get-messages request.
@odata.nextLink.title: @Odata.Next Link

items.name: Query Emails
items.description: Primary tool for querying Outlook emails with custom OData filters. Build precise server-side filters for dates, read status, importance, subjects, attachments, and conversations. Best for structured queries on message metadata. Returns up to 100 messages per request with pagination support. • Server-side filters: dates, importance, isRead, hasAttachments, subjects, conversationId • CRITICAL: Always check response['@odata.nextLink'] for pagination • Limitations: Recipient/sender/category filters require OUTLOOK_SEARCH_MESSAGES • For keyword/body search: Use OUTLOOK_SEARCH_MESSAGES (KQL syntax)

filter.description:
OData $filter query string to filter email messages. Syntax: 'field operator value' combined with 'and', 'or', 'not'.

        **IMPORTANT - DO NOT include 'folder' in this filter:**
        - The 'folder' field is NOT a valid filter property for messages
        - To specify which folder to query, use the separate 'folder' parameter (e.g., folder="inbox")
        - WRONG: filter="folder eq 'inbox' and isRead eq false"
        - CORRECT: folder="inbox", filter="isRead eq false"

        **Operators:** eq, ne, lt, le, gt, ge, startswith(), endswith(), contains() (limited support), any()

        **Common Fields (Server-Side Filterable):**
        - `isRead` - Boolean: true/false
        - `importance` - String: 'low', 'normal', 'high'
        - `subject` - String (exact match or startswith)
        - `hasAttachments` - Boolean: true/false
        - `receivedDateTime`, `sentDateTime` - DateTime (ISO 8601: '2025-10-01T00:00:00Z')
        - `conversationId` - String (exact match)
        - `categories` - Array (use any() operator)
        - `isDraft`, `isRead`, `flag/flagStatus` - Boolean/String flags

        **Sender Filtering (SUPPORTED):**
        - `from/emailAddress/address` - Filter by sender email: `from/emailAddress/address eq 'user@example.com'`
        - `sender/emailAddress/address` - Filter by sender: `sender/emailAddress/address eq 'user@example.com'`
        - Use startswith() for partial matches: `startswith(from/emailAddress/address, 'user@')`

        **NOT FILTERABLE - Use OUTLOOK_SEARCH_MESSAGES instead:**
        - `toRecipients`, `ccRecipients`, `bccRecipients` - Recipient filtering requires KQL search
        - `body/content` - Body text search requires KQL search

        **Date Filtering:**
        - Dates MUST be in ISO 8601 format with time zone: 2025-10-01T00:00:00Z
        - IMPORTANT: DateTimeOffset values are NOT enclosed in quotes (Microsoft Graph requirement)
        - Use ge (>=), gt (>), le (<=), lt (<) operators
        - Example: `receivedDateTime ge 2025-10-01T00:00:00Z and receivedDateTime lt 2025-10-02T00:00:00Z`
        - The validator will automatically remove quotes if you accidentally include them

        **String Filtering:**
        - Exact match: `subject eq 'Meeting Notes'`
        - Starts with: `startswith(subject, '[Action Required]')`
        - Escape single quotes by doubling: `subject eq 'Owner''s Manual'`

        **Combining Conditions:**
        - AND: `isRead eq false and importance eq 'high'`
        - OR: `importance eq 'high' or importance eq 'low'`
        - NOT: `not (isRead eq true)`
        - Grouping: `(isRead eq false or importance eq 'high') and hasAttachments eq true`
examples: isRead eq false and receivedDateTime ge 2025-10-01T00:00:00Z
importance eq 'high' and hasAttachments eq true
isDraft eq false and isRead eq false and importance eq 'high'
(isRead eq false or importance eq 'high') and receivedDateTime ge 2025-10-01T00:00:00Z
(isRead eq false or importance eq 'high') and hasAttachments eq true
from/emailAddress/address eq 'boss@company.com' and isRead eq false
filter.human_parameter_description: Use a simple expression to narrow results by things like unread status, dates, subject, or attachments. For example: isRead eq false or receivedDateTime ge 2025-10-01T00:00:00Z. Note: Datetime values should NOT have quotes around them.
filter.title: Filter

folder.description: ID or well-known name of the mail folder. Well-known names: 'inbox', 'sentitems', 'drafts', 'deleteditems', 'outbox', 'junkemail' (case-insensitive). Or use a valid folder ID.
folder.human_parameter_description: The mail folder to search within, like 'inbox' or 'sentitems'. You can type a familiar name or paste a specific folder ID.
folder.title: Folder

orderby.description: Comma-separated sort keys with direction. Format: 'field asc' or 'field desc'. Common fields: receivedDateTime, sentDateTime, subject, importance, from. NOTE: Ordering may be automatically disabled by Microsoft Graph API when using certain filters (e.g., subject exact match, conversationId) to avoid 'InefficientFilter' errors. In those cases, results will be unsorted.
orderby.human_parameter_description: Set how to sort the results, like 'receivedDateTime desc' for newest first. In some cases sorting may be ignored by Microsoft when certain filters are used.
orderby.title: Orderby

select.description: List of message properties to include in the response (accepts comma-separated string or list). Reduces data transfer and improves performance. Common fields: id, subject, from, toRecipients, ccRecipients, receivedDateTime, sentDateTime, hasAttachments, importance, isRead, body, bodyPreview, categories, conversationId, webLink, internetMessageHeaders, isDraft, flag. Leave empty to return all fields.
select.human_parameter_description: Choose which fields to include so the response stays concise. Leave blank to return all available details.
select.title: Select

skip.description: Number of messages to skip for pagination. NOTE: For large result sets, prefer using '@odata.nextLink' from responses instead of manual skip.
skip.human_parameter_description: How many messages to skip from the start, useful for paging through results. Usually you can leave this at 0 and follow the next page link instead.
skip.title: Skip

top.description: Maximum number of messages to return per request (1-1000). Default is 100. IMPORTANT: For large mailboxes, always check response['@odata.nextLink'] to fetch remaining messages. Pagination example: 1) Call with top=100, 2) Check if '@odata.nextLink' exists in response, 3) If present, make a new request to that full URL (includes $skiptoken), 4) Repeat until '@odata.nextLink' is absent.
top.human_parameter_description: How many messages to return in this request. Use a smaller number for faster responses; you can page for more if needed.

user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or identifier of the mailbox you want to query. Use 'me' to search your own currently connected account.

items.name: Search Outlook messages
items.description: Search Outlook messages using powerful KQL syntax. Supports sender (from:), recipient (to:, cc:), subject, date filters (received:, sent:), attachments, and boolean logic. Only works with Microsoft 365/Enterprise accounts (no @hotmail.com/@outlook.com). Examples: 'from:user@example.com AND received>=2025-10-01', 'to:info@jcdn.nl AND subject:invoice', 'received>today-30 AND hasattachment:yes'

input_parameters.description: Searches Outlook messages for Microsoft 365/Enterprise accounts using the Microsoft Search API.

enable_top_results.description: If `true`, sorts results by relevance; otherwise, sorts by date in descending order (newest first).
enable_top_results.human_parameter_description: Show the most relevant results first instead of the newest. Turn this on when relevance matters more than date.
enable_top_results.title: Enable Top Results

fromEmail.description: Filter messages by sender email address or domain. Supports exact email ('user@example.com') or domain matching ('example.com'). Legacy parameter - prefer using 'from:email@example.com' in the query parameter for more flexibility. Note: Only Microsoft 365/Enterprise accounts are supported (no @hotmail.com or @outlook.com).
fromEmail.human_parameter_description: The sender’s email address or domain to filter by. Use this to only see messages from a specific person or company.
fromEmail.title: From Email

from_index.description: The 0-based starting index for pagination. To paginate: check response['value'][0]['hitsContainers'][0]['moreResultsAvailable']. If true, call again with from_index += size (e.g., 0 → 25 → 50). Message ID is in hits[]['hitId'], not hits[]['resource']['id'].
from_index.human_parameter_description: Where to start in the results list, beginning at 0. Increase this number to move to the next page of results.
from_index.title: From Index

hasAttachments.description: Filters messages based on the presence of attachments. Legacy parameter - prefer using 'hasattachment:yes' or 'hasattachment:no' in the query parameter.
hasAttachments.human_parameter_description: Choose whether to only show emails that include file attachments. Turn on to find messages with attachments, or off to exclude them.
hasAttachments.title: Has Attachments

query.description:
KQL (Keyword Query Language) search query string. Supports advanced syntax for precise searches.

**Basic Syntax:**
- Simple keywords: 'budget report'
- Exact phrases: '"quarterly review"'
- Boolean operators: 'urgent AND deadline' or 'invoice OR receipt'

**Property Filters (prefix:value):**
- from: Sender email - 'from:user@example.com' or 'from:example.com'
- to: Recipient email - 'to:info@jcdn.nl'
- cc: CC recipient - 'cc:manager@example.com'
- subject: Subject line - 'subject:invoice'
- received: Date received - 'received:2025-10-01' or 'received>=2025-10-01'
- sent: Date sent - 'sent:2025-10-01' or 'sent>=2025-10-01'
- hasattachment: Has files - 'hasattachment:yes' or 'hasattachment:no'

**Date Operators:**
- Exact: 'received:2025-10-01'
- Greater/equal: 'received>=2025-10-01'
- Less/equal: 'received<=2025-10-31'
- Range: 'received:2025-10-01..2025-10-31'
- Relative: 'received>today-7' (last 7 days)

**Combining Filters:**
- AND: 'from:user@example.com AND subject:invoice'
- OR: 'to:sales@example.com OR to:support@example.com'
- Complex: 'from:example.com AND (subject:urgent OR subject:important) AND received>=2025-10-01'

**REQUIRED**: At least one search criterion must be provided - either this query parameter OR one of the legacy filters (fromEmail, subject, hasAttachments). Empty searches are not supported.
query.human_parameter_description: What you want to search for in your mailbox. You can type simple words or use filters like from:, to:, subject:, received:, and hasattachment: to narrow the results.
query.title: Query

size.description: The maximum number of search results to return per page. Use with from_index for pagination.
size.human_parameter_description: How many results to return per page. Use a larger number to see more results at once.
size.title: Size

subject.description: Text to search for within the message subject line. Legacy parameter - prefer using 'subject:text' in the query parameter for more control. Example: Instead of subject='invoice', use query='subject:invoice AND received>=2025-10-01'
subject.human_parameter_description: Words to look for in the email subject line. Helpful when you remember part of the subject you’re trying to find.
subject.title: Subject

items.name: Send email
items.description: Sends an email with subject, body, recipients, and an optional attachment via Microsoft Graph API. Supports comma-separated email addresses in the to_email field for multiple recipients. Attachments require a non-empty file with valid name and mimetype.

mimetype.description: The MIME type of the file
mimetype.title: Mimetype

name.description: The filename that will be used when uploading the file to the destination service
name.title: Name

s3key.description: The S3 key of a publicly accessible file, typically returned from a previous download action that stored the file in S3. This key references an existing file that can be uploaded to another service.
s3key.title: S3Key

attachment.description: Optional file to attach. If provided, its name, mimetype, and content must be valid and non-empty.
attachment.human_parameter_description: Attach a file to include with your email, like a document or image.
attachment.title: Attachment

bcc_emails.description: List of email addresses for BCC recipients. Each email should be a separate string in the array. Do NOT pass comma-separated values as a single string.
bcc_emails.human_parameter_description: People you want to copy without other recipients seeing their addresses. Add each email separately.
bcc_emails.title: Bcc Emails

body.description: The content of the email body as a plain string (plain text or HTML based on `is_html`). Do not pass structured objects; provide only the raw text/HTML content.
examples: Hello team, please find the attached report.
body.human_parameter_description: What you want to say in the email. Enter plain text or include HTML if you turn on HTML format.
body.title: Body

cc_emails.description: List of email addresses for CC recipients. Each email should be a separate string in the array. Do NOT pass comma-separated values as a single string.
cc_emails.human_parameter_description: People you want to keep in the loop. Add each email separately so they receive a copy.
cc_emails.title: Cc Emails

from_address.description: Optional From address to set on the message (send as/on behalf). Provide a single email address. Requires appropriate mailbox permissions.
from_address.human_parameter_description: Email address to appear in the From field. Use when sending as or on behalf of another mailbox (requires permissions).
from_address.title: From Address

is_html.description: Specifies if the email body is HTML; `True` for HTML, `False` for plain text.
is_html.human_parameter_description: Turn this on if your message includes HTML formatting (headings, links, bold). Leave off for plain text.
is_html.title: Is Html

save_to_sent_items.description: Indicates if the email should be saved in 'Sent Items'.
save_to_sent_items.human_parameter_description: Choose whether to keep a copy of this message in your Sent folder.
save_to_sent_items.title: Save To Sent Items

subject.description: The subject line of the email.
subject.human_parameter_description: What you want the email to be titled so recipients know what it's about.
subject.title: Subject

to.description: The primary recipient's email address(es). You can provide a single email or multiple emails separated by commas. For CC/BCC recipients, use the respective fields.
to.human_parameter_description: Who you want to send the email to. Enter one address or multiple separated by commas.

to_name.description: The display name of the primary recipient.
to_name.human_parameter_description: The display name for the main recipient so their name appears alongside their email address.
to_name.title: To Name

user_id.description: The user's email address or the alias 'me' to represent the authenticated user.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or ID of the mailbox to send from. Use 'me' to send from your own account.
user_id.title: User Id

body.description: Response body is empty on success. No content is returned when the email is successfully accepted for sending.

successful.title: Successful

items.name: Update calendar event
items.description: Updates specified fields of an existing Outlook calendar event. Implementation note: To avoid unintentionally clearing properties, the action first fetches the existing event, merges only the provided fields, and then PATCHes the merged updates. Unspecified fields remain unchanged.

emailAddress.description: The email address and optional name of the attendee.

address.description: The complete email address of the attendee.
address.title: Address

name.description: The display name of the attendee.
name.title: Name

emailAddress.title: EmailAddress

type.description: The attendee's type. Valid values are 'required' or 'optional'.
type.title: Type

attendees.description: Attendee list for the event. If provided, replaces the existing attendees. If omitted, attendees remain unchanged.
attendees.human_parameter_description: People to invite. Supplying a list here will replace any current attendees. Omit to keep existing attendees.
attendees.title: Attendees

content.description: The actual content of the event body, corresponding to the specified contentType.
examples: Let's meet to discuss the updated project details.
content.title: Content

contentType.description: The format of the event body. Must be 'Text' for plain text or 'HTML' for HTML content.
contentType.title: Contenttype

body.description: Event body with content type ('Text' or 'HTML') and the content. If omitted, the existing body remains unchanged.
body.human_parameter_description: Details or agenda for the event. Provide only if you want to modify the current body.
body.title: Body

categories.description: Category names to associate with the event. If provided (even empty), replaces the existing categories. If omitted, categories remain unchanged.
categories.human_parameter_description: Color labels or tags to apply. Providing a list (including empty) will replace existing categories. Omit to keep current categories.
categories.title: Categories

end_datetime.description: New end date and time for the event. Provide together with a time zone, or the current event's time zone will be used. Must be after start_datetime if both are provided. If omitted, the end time remains unchanged.
end_datetime.human_parameter_description: When the event should finish. If you do not provide a time zone, the existing event time zone will be reused.
end_datetime.title: End Datetime

event_id.description: The unique identifier of the calendar event to be updated. This ID can be obtained from the OUTLOOK_LIST_EVENTS action.
event_id.human_parameter_description: The unique ID of the calendar event you want to update. You can get this from a previous event search or list.
event_id.title: Event Id

location.description: Event location. Can be provided as a simple string (e.g., 'Conference Room A') which will be converted to displayName, or as a dictionary with fields like displayName, address, etc. If provided, replaces the existing primary location. Omit to leave unchanged.
location.human_parameter_description: Where the event takes place. Provide a simple name like 'Noida' or an object with displayName and other details. Omit to keep current location.
location.title: Location

show_as.description: Availability status for the event. Valid values: 'free', 'tentative', 'busy', 'oof'. If omitted, the existing status remains unchanged.
show_as.human_parameter_description: How your availability appears during the event (free, tentative, busy, out of office). Omit to keep current setting.
show_as.title: Show As

start_datetime.description: New start date and time for the event. Provide together with a time zone, or the current event's time zone will be used. If omitted, the start time remains unchanged.
start_datetime.human_parameter_description: When the event should begin. If you do not provide a time zone, the existing event time zone will be reused.
start_datetime.title: Start Datetime

subject.description: New subject for the event. If provided as an empty string, the subject will be cleared. If omitted, the existing subject remains unchanged.
subject.human_parameter_description: The title you want to show on the calendar for this event. Provide an empty string to clear it; omit to keep the current subject.
subject.title: Subject

time_zone.description: Time zone for the provided start_datetime and/or end_datetime (IANA or Windows time zone names). If omitted, the existing event's time zone is used.
time_zone.human_parameter_description: The time zone to apply to the provided start and end times. If not supplied, the event's current time zone is preserved.
time_zone.title: Time Zone

user_id.description: The identifier of the user whose calendar event is to be updated. Accepts the user's principal name, ID, or 'me' for the currently authenticated user.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or identifier of the user whose calendar you want to update. Use 'me' to update your own calendar.
user_id.title: User Id

items.name: Update Contact
items.description: Updates an existing Outlook contact, identified by `contact_id` for the specified `user_id`, requiring at least one other field to be modified.

birthday.human_parameter_description: The contact’s birthday in YYYY-MM-DD format. Include it if you want to keep personal details or set reminders.
birthday.title: Birthday

businessPhones.human_parameter_description: Work phone numbers for the contact. Add one or more numbers if you want them saved under business phones.
businessPhones.title: Business Phones

categories.description: Categories for organizing the contact.
categories.human_parameter_description: Tags or labels to group this contact, such as 'Clients' or 'Vendors'. Use categories to organize and filter your contacts.
categories.title: Categories

companyName.human_parameter_description: The company this person works for. This helps you organize and search your contacts.
companyName.title: Company Name

contact_id.description: Unique identifier of the contact to update.
contact_id.human_parameter_description: The unique ID of the contact you want to change. You can get this from a previous contact search or list.
contact_id.title: Contact Id

department.human_parameter_description: The department the contact belongs to. Optional but helpful for sorting and filtering.
department.title: Department

displayName.description: Contact's full display name.
displayName.human_parameter_description: The full name as you want it to appear for this contact. Leave it blank to keep the current name.
displayName.title: Display Name

emailAddresses.human_parameter_description: One or more email addresses for this contact. You can include the address and optionally a display name for each.

address.title: Address

name.description: The display name of the person or entity.
name.title: Name

emailAddresses.title: Email Addresses

givenName.human_parameter_description: The contact’s first name. Provide this only if you want to update it.
givenName.title: Given Name

homePhones.human_parameter_description: Home phone numbers for the contact. Add one or more numbers if you want them saved under home phones.
homePhones.title: Home Phones

jobTitle.human_parameter_description: The person’s job title. Useful for context when viewing or searching your contacts.
jobTitle.title: Job Title

mobilePhone.human_parameter_description: The contact’s mobile/cell number. Include this if you want to set or change it.
mobilePhone.title: Mobile Phone

notes.description: Personal notes about the contact (maps to 'personalNotes' in Microsoft Graph API).
examples: Met at the annual tech conference. Interested in collaboration.

notes.title: Notes

officeLocation.human_parameter_description: Where the contact works or sits, such as a building or room. Add this to provide helpful location context.
officeLocation.title: Office Location

surname.human_parameter_description: The contact’s last name. Provide this only if you want to update it.
surname.title: Surname

user_id.description: User's identifier; 'me' for the signed-in user, or user's principal name/ID.

assistantName.description: The name of the contact's assistant.

countryOrRegion.description: The country or region. It's a free-format string value, for example, 'United States'.

categories.description: The categories associated with the contact.

items.name: Update email message
items.description: Updates specified properties of an existing email message; `message_id` must identify a valid message within the specified `user_id`'s mailbox.

bcc_recipients.description: List of BCC recipients; replaces all existing BCCs. Omitting this field removes all current BCC recipients.
bcc_recipients.human_parameter_description: People you want to blind-copy on the message. Providing a list here replaces any existing BCCs; leave it empty to remove all BCC recipients.

address.description: The SMTP email address of the recipient. For example, 'kat.hughes@example.com'.
address.title: Address

name.description: Optional display name for the recipient (e.g., 'Katherine Hughes').
name.title: Name

bcc_recipients.title: Bcc Recipients

content.description: The actual email body content, formatted according to the `contentType`. For example, if contentType is 'HTML', this would be HTML markup.
examples: This is a plain text update.
content.title: Content

contentType.description: Specifies the format of the email body content. Must be either 'Text' (for plain text) or 'HTML' (for HTML markup).
contentType.title: Contenttype

body.description: New body content (Text or HTML). If omitted, the existing message body remains unchanged.
body.human_parameter_description: The new message body you want to set. Include the content type (Text or HTML) and the content; skip this if you don't want to change the body.
body.title: Body

cc_recipients.description: List of CC recipients; replaces all existing CCs. Omitting this field removes all current CC recipients.
cc_recipients.human_parameter_description: People you want to copy on the message. Providing a list here replaces any existing CCs; leave it empty to remove all CC recipients.

address.description: The SMTP email address of the recipient. For example, 'kat.hughes@example.com'.
address.title: Address

name.description: Optional display name for the recipient (e.g., 'Katherine Hughes').
name.title: Name

cc_recipients.title: Cc Recipients

importance.description: New importance level ('low', 'normal', 'high'). If omitted, importance is set to 'normal'.
importance.human_parameter_description: How important the message should appear: low, normal, or high. If you're not sure, leave it as normal.
importance.title: Importance

is_read.description: Mark message as read (True) or unread (False). If omitted, read status remains unchanged.
is_read.human_parameter_description: Whether to mark the message as read or unread. Leave this out to keep its current status.
is_read.title: Is Read

message_id.description: The unique identifier of the email message to be updated. This ID is typically obtained from listing messages or creating/sending a message. URL-encoded IDs are automatically decoded before use.
message_id.human_parameter_description: The unique ID of the email message you want to update. You can get this from a previous list, search, or create message step. URL-encoded IDs are automatically decoded.
message_id.title: Message Id

subject.description: New subject line. If omitted, the existing subject remains unchanged. Provide empty string to clear the subject.
subject.human_parameter_description: The new subject line for the message. If you don't provide one, the current subject stays; use an empty string to clear it.
subject.title: Subject

to_recipients.description: List of TO recipients; replaces all existing TOs. Omitting this field removes all current TO recipients.
to_recipients.human_parameter_description: The main recipients of the message. Providing a list here replaces existing To recipients; leave it empty to remove all To recipients.

address.description: The SMTP email address of the recipient. For example, 'kat.hughes@example.com'.
address.title: Address

name.description: Optional display name for the recipient (e.g., 'Katherine Hughes').
name.title: Name

to_recipients.title: To Recipients

user_id.description: The UPN (User Principal Name) of the user whose mailbox contains the message, or 'me' for the currently authenticated user. This determines whose message is updated.
user_id.human_parameter_description: The email address or identifier of the mailbox that contains the message you want to update. Use 'me' to update a message in your own mailbox.
user_id.title: User Id

items.name: Update mailbox settings
items.description: Tool to update mailbox settings for the signed-in user. Use when you need to configure automatic replies, default time zone, language, or working hours. Example: schedule automatic replies for vacation.

externalAudience.description: The set of audience external to the signed-in user's organization who will receive the ExternalReplyMessage. Possible values: none, contactsOnly, all.
externalAudience.title: Externalaudience

externalReplyMessage.description: The automatic reply to send to the specified external audience, if Status is AlwaysEnabled or Scheduled.
externalReplyMessage.title: Externalreplymessage

internalReplyMessage.description: The automatic reply to send to the audience internal to the signed-in user's organization.
internalReplyMessage.title: Internalreplymessage

dateTime.description: A single point of time in a combined date and time representation ({date}T{time}; for example, 2017-08-29T04:00:00.0000000).
dateTime.title: Datetime

timeZone.description: Represents a time zone, for example, 'Pacific Standard Time'.
timeZone.title: Timezone

scheduledEndDateTime.description: The date and time that automatic replies are set to end, if Status is set to Scheduled.

timeZone.title: Timezone

automaticRepliesSetting.human_parameter_description: Configure your out-of-office auto-reply. Choose whether it's on, set the schedule, and write the messages people will receive.
automaticRepliesSetting.title: Automatic Replies Setting

displayName.description: A name representing the user's locale in natural language, for example, 'English (United States)'.
displayName.title: Displayname

locale.description: A locale representation for the user, which includes the user's preferred language and country/region. For example, 'en-us'. Language follows ISO 639-1 codes; country follows ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 codes.
locale.title: Locale

language.human_parameter_description: Select your preferred language/locale so dates, times, and other mailbox details appear the way you expect.
language.title: Language

timeZone.description: Default mailbox time zone (e.g., 'Pacific Standard Time').
timeZone.human_parameter_description: Enter the time zone you want your mailbox to use, so events and automatic replies show the correct local time. Example: Pacific Standard Time.
timeZone.title: Time Zone

dayOfWeek.description: Day of the week for the offset rule.
dayOfWeek.title: Dayofweek

time.description: Time of day when the offset starts in HH:mm:ss.
time.title: Time

standardOffset.description: Standard time offset rule for custom time zone.

timeZone.description: The time zone to which the working hours apply.

workingHours.description: Working hours configuration for the user.

workingHours.title: Working Hours
